members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In  2005,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  initiated  the  Clean  Energy  and 
Environment Program to foster clean energy development in Asia and the Pacific and to help 
address climate change and energy security. One of the program’s key components is the 
Carbon Market Initiative (CMI), which provides technical support and up-front financing to clean 
energy projects with greenhouse gas (GHG) mitigation benefits. ADB proposed the CMI in its 
39th Annual Governors’ Meeting in Hyderabad, India, and it was approved by the Board on 20 
November 2006.1
2.  The CMI is a value-added service extended to clean energy and energy efficiency 
projects in Asia and the Pacific that are suitable for ADB financing. Through the CMI, ADB can 
utilize the carbon market as a tool and offer technical and financial services to developing 
member countries (DMCs) in conjunction with regular financing operations. The CMI boosts 
ADB’s efforts in promoting energy efficiency, renewable energy, and urban sanitation sector 
projects where carbon credit revenues can enhance project viability. 
3.  The CMI has three components:  
(i)  an upfront carbon cofinancing vehicle through the Asia Pacific Carbon Fund 
(APCF);2
(ii)  technical assistance (TA) for project preparation and implementation through the 
technical support facility (TSF); and 
(iii)  marketing support for carbon credits through the credit marketing facility. 
4.  This proposed regional technical assistance (RETA) aims to operationalize the CMI’s 
TSF. The concept paper for this RETA was approved by the vice-president of Knowledge 
Management and Sustainable Development on 8 June(cid:3) 20073 for $10 million.4(cid:3)In December 
2006, as immediate capacity-building assistance for CMI as part of the TSF, a RETA5 for 
Preparing Clean Energy Projects Eligible for the Clean Development Mechanism, financed by 
the Japan Special Fund, was(cid:3)approved for $840,000. As of end October 2007, regarding the 
ongoing work in preparing clean energy projects, there are already 25 projects (with over 
40 subprojects) and additional 20–30 projects requiring support during the coming year. Many 
donors supporting climate change initiatives in Asia have expressed immediate support and 
contributions to the TSF. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  Access  to  energy  is  essential  to  ensure  sustained  economic  growth  and  poverty 
reduction. In response to expected high rates of economic growth, the demand for energy in

Asia  and  the  Pacific  is  projected  to  increase  significantly  in  the  next  30  years.  However, 
continued reliance on fossil fuels as dominant sources of energy will have adverse impacts on 
the environment. The resultant increasing GHG level in the atmosphere, global warming, and 
climate change have necessitated a shift toward cleaner energy sources and a low-carbon 
global economy to ensure environmental integrity and sustainable growth. In this regard, ADB's 
energy operations must continue to focus on accelerating the use of clean energy in DMCs. As 
early as 2000, an energy policy review6 stated that ADB would help DMCs to formulate and 
implement viable clean energy projects, preferably with private sector involvement, to provide 
electricity in remote areas and improve the quality of life of the rural poor. In recent years, ADB 
has further recognized the paramount importance of broadening the application of clean energy 
in DMCs and using existing mechanisms, including the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) 
under the Kyoto Protocol, which generates extra revenue for DMCs through projects that reduce 
GHG emissions and contribute to climate change mitigation.  
6.  The  CDM  can  accelerate  clean  energy  projects’  impact  and  natural  resource 
conservation in DMCs while helping them to meet their Kyoto Protocol commitments. Such 
activities yield both local and global environmental benefits, and the CDM ensures additional 
benefits to those project developers who opt for cleaner projects and activities. Substantial 
synergies exist between ADB’s objectives of promoting sustainable growth and clean energy 
projects and the CDM’s objectives. However, the CDM is a complex process, and most DMCs 
are not equipped to harness CDM’s benefits in a competitive way. Given these circumstances, 
ADB can play a critical role in helping DMCs to realize the CDM’s potential.   
7.  The  proposed  RETA  will  maximize  the  synergy  between  CMI  and  other  ongoing 
initiatives  and  programs  that  promote  clean  energy  projects,  e.g.,  the  Energy  Efficiency 
Initiative;7 Renewable  Energy,  Energy  Efficiency  and  Climate  Change  Program  (REACH);8
Innovation  and  Efficiency  Initiative; 9  and  Global  Environment  Facility,  to  enhance  the 
development effectiveness of ADB’s Clean Energy and Environment Program.(cid:3) For projects 
supported by operations departments as well as the previously-mentioned schemes, this RETA 
is specifically designed to assist DMCs in completing the necessary Kyoto Protocol procedures 
in order to benefit from the global carbon market. 
8.  ADB has a portfolio of projects that could be designed or retrofitted to become cleaner, 
yielding a significant quantity of carbon credits. A preliminary review of ADB’s project pipeline 
for the next 3 years reveals that more than 80 projects across various operations departments 
have or could incorporate components eligible for the CDM. Use of the CDM can translate into 
multiple benefits for DMCs through an enhanced revenue stream and a greater number of clean 
energy projects. Operations departments’ staff need support for screening projects for CDM 
potential and in providing assistance to DMCs for further actions in this regard.  
9.  The proposed RETA operationalizes the TSF to help ADB’s operations departments 
assess the eligibility of ADB-supported projects for receiving carbon revenues. Further, the TSF

will support on going project monitoring during their financing and operational phases to ensure 
that DMC project developers and sponsors execute projects in accordance with the carbon 
market and receive benefits from it. Adequate training and country consultations must also 
occur to ensure a continuous pipeline of candidate projects. 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the RETA will be to contribute to low-carbon economic growth in Asia and 
the Pacific. The outcome of the RETA will be to increase the number of clean energy projects 
with GHG abatement benefits across Asia and the Pacific. The RETA will (i) enhance the 
technical knowledge of project developers and sponsors in DMCs to conceptualize clean energy 
projects for possible ADB financing, (ii) build the pipeline of clean energy projects suitable for 
ADB financing and eligible for the CDM, with special focus on expanding the geographical and 
sectoral coverage of such projects, (iii) oversee the implementation of CDM components during 
the project execution and operational phases, and (iv) assist with the issuance and transfer of 
certified emissions reductions (CERs), or “carbon credits”, including credits contracted with 
CMI’s APCF.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  ADB will carry out the work under the RETA in close coordination with the operations 
departments. The RETA activities will include those outlined in the following. 
(i) Capacity development and project identification. The RETA will: 
(a)  Help assess the capacities of DMC governments, agencies, and other 
project developers to identify and implement CDM-eligible clean energy 
projects, and conduct targeted CDM technical workshops for countries 
and  regions  with  project  opportunities  in  the  near-  to  mid-term.  The 
training  will  focus  on  those  directly  involved  in  the  development  of 
identified  projects(cid:3) and  staff  from  projects’  executing  agencies.  On  a 
limited and targeted basis, the TA will assist the capacity building of 
designated  national  authorities  (DNAs)10 within  DMCs  with  concrete 
project proposals. Also, ADB staff knowledge will be enhanced through 
briefings  provided  by  experts  under  this  TA  and  by  participation  in 
country-specific workshops. 
(b)  Help the operations departments undertake a preliminary assessment of 
projects, and identify projects with GHG abatement potential. The TA will 
also provide technical inputs into country consultation missions, i.e., in the 
case of public sector projects, to identify clean energy projects potentially 
eligible for the CDM and their inclusion in the country operations business 
plans (COBPs). In addition to hands-on support, the TA team will also 
provide useful screening tools and briefing notes on lessons learned to 
operations staff and consultants. 
                                                
10DNAs are responsible for evaluating  whether a proposed CDM project activity contributes to the country’s 
sustainable development. Host country approval by the DNA is required before a project can be validated by 
designated operations entities (DOEs, see footnote 11).

4
(ii) Project development and CDM processing support. The RETA will: 
(a)  Assist  in  conducting  preliminary  screening  of  projects’  CDM  eligibility 
under CDM international rules; performing CDM-related due diligence in 
tandem with the loan preparation process, i.e., most commonly through 
project preparatory TA for public sector projects; and supporting project 
developers and sponsors in writing project design documents (PDDs) and 
when  required,  new  CDM  baseline  and  monitoring  methodologies. 
Projects with financing needs beyond debt and equity support by ADB 
operations departments will be introduced at this stage to CMI’s APCF for 
potential upfront financing against future delivery of CERs. 
(b)   Help project developers obtain host country approval from DNAs and 
successful validation from the designated operational entities11 (DOEs), 
and register them with the CDM Executive Board. 
(iii)  Project implementation and monitoring support. The RETA will: 
(a) Monitor the implementation of project milestones during financing and 
construction as specified in the PDD and the specific CDM methodology 
used, as agreed with ADB. 
(b)   Monitor  CDM  data  as  specified  in  the  PDD  and  as  described  in  the 
monitoring methodology used. 
(c)   Assist the project participants in meeting requirements for verification and 
certification by the DOEs. Provide technical guidance to meet the DOE 
and the CDM Executive Board requirements. 
(d)   Assist the project participants in meeting requirements for CER issuance 
and transfer.  
C.  Total Amount and Financing 
12.  The total amount of the TA is estimated at $4.04 million.12 It will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  the  governments  of  Austria  ($1  million),  Finland  (€700,000),  and  Luxembourg 
(€500,000), the Spanish Cooperation Fund for Technical Assistance ($1 million), and the Swiss 
Cooperation  Fund  for  Consulting  Services  ($300,000),  and  administered  by  ADB.13 It  will 
support equipment,14 training, seminars and workshops, publications and information services, 
CDM validation costs, fees and remuneration for international and national consultants and 
technical experts, miscellaneous administration and support costs, and TA consultants and ADB 
resource staff members who participate in country programming and project missions. The 
detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2.
                                                
11DOEs  are  third-party  certification  organizations  accredited  by  the  CDM  Executive  Board  to  review  project 
documents and validate the project against CDM international rules.  
12 The exact total amount of the TA will be determined upon transfer and conversion of funds from the governments 
of Finland and Luxembourg.  
13 Disbursements from the donors will be prorated. 
14The equipment will be procured and disposed in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
amended from time to time).

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB,  as  the  Executing  Agency,  is  expected  to  implement  the  RETA  through  the 
Regional and Sustainable Development Department’s Energy, Transport, and Water Division 
(RSID) in close collaboration with the operations departments(cid:3)using the same channels and 
communication lines established throughout the implementation of initiatives stated in para. 7. 
ADB will also coordinate closely with other project sponsors.(cid:3)To date, no specific DMC has been 
identified in whose territory any specific activity of the RETA will be undertaken; however, any 
activity funded by this RETA will only commence in a particular DMC after ADB has received a 
no-objection in writing from the government of the DMC.  
14.  The RETA will begin in(cid:3)December 2007 and will be carried out over a 36-month period, 
concluding in December 2010.  
15.  Two individual international experts (senior carbon market expert and CDM expert) and 
two individual national experts (program coordinator and CDM expert) will be engaged for 
24 person-months each over the 36-month period under the direct supervision of RSID. Detailed 
terms of reference are in Appendix 3. All consultants will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
16.  In addition, the amount of $1.55 million has been budgeted to recruit international and 
national technical experts on an as-and-when-required basis. These experts will be recruited as 
individual consultants/consulting firms depending on the requirements of specific assignments 
identified  during  the  implementation  period.  It  is  envisaged  that  these  experts  will  include 
environmental  specialists,  energy  engineers,  CDM  experts,  CDM  technical  advisors,  legal 
experts, CDM validation experts, and capacity-building experts.15 Detailed terms of reference 
will be determined once specific projects are identified during the implementation. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION AND DECISION 
17.  The President recommends that the Board approve ADB administering a portion of 
technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of €700,000 for the Implementation of the 
Technical Support Facility under the Carbon Market Initiative, to be financed on a grant basis by 
the Government of Finland. If the Board approves ADB administering the technical assistance, 
the  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  will  approve  (i)  ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000, to 
be financed on a grant basis by the Government of Austria, (ii) ADB administering a portion of 
technical  assistance  not  exceeding  €500,000,  to  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the 
Government  of  Luxembourg,  (iii)  ADB  administering  a  portion  of  technical  assistance  not 
exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,000,000,  to  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Spanish 
Cooperation Fund for Technical Assistance, and (iv) ADB administering a portion of technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000, to be financed on a grant basis by the 
Swiss  Cooperation  Fund  for  Consulting  Services,  for  the  Implementation  of  the  Technical 
Support Facility under the Carbon Market Initiative.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS  
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be implemented in consultation with the following 
relevant bodies: the Asian Development Bank (ADB), Carbon Market Initiative (CMI) team, 
project participants, and consultants. The team of international consultants will have expertise in 
(i)  overall  carbon  market  dynamics  and  requirements,  (ii)  technical  Carbon  Development 
Mechanism  (CDM)  projects,  and  (iii)  CDM  Executive  Board  requirements.  The  national 
consultants will have expertise similar to, and will coordinate their work with, the international 
consultants. Under the supervision of the Energy, Transport and Water Division (RSID) project 
specialist, the senior carbon market expert will be the consultants’ team leader and will manage 
the  team’s  activities.  The  team’s  services  are  mainly  targeted  to  the  mission  leaders  and 
members  of  ADB’s  operations  departments  and  their  counterparts  in  developing  member 
countries (DMCs). 
A.  Individual International Consultants 
1. Senior Carbon Market Expert and Team Leader (24 person-months).
2.  The consultant will undertake the following activities: 
(i)  report to the RSID project specialist on the project’s management; 
(ii)  assist with the development of candidate lists for consultant team positions, and 
advise the RSID project specialist during the selection process; 
(iii)  supervise the team to ensure that all deliverables are submitted on schedule; 
(iv)  review existing information and data on the CDM in DMCs and ADB pipeline 
projects;
(v)  identify,  and,  in  consultation  with  the  RSID  project  specialist,  undertake 
necessary capacity-building and project identification activities in countries and 
regions with limited project pipelines;  
(vi)  recommend to the RSID project specialist projects from the ADB pipeline with 
strong  CDM  potential,  by  considering  evaluations  from  the  operations 
departments  staff,  international  and  national  CDM  experts,  and(cid:3) other  team 
members; 
(vii)  provide technical advice to the operations departments, including identification of 
ADB pipeline projects that have a high probability of being registered as CDM 
projects, and review projects’ evaluations; 
(viii)  coordinate the team in the preparation of the CDM assessment report, project 
design document (PDD), and procurement of the written approval of the host 
party and other parties involved; 
(ix)  ensure that the selected designated operational entity (DOE) for each project 
submits  a  validation  report  using  the  CDM  project  activity  registration  and 
validation report form to request for registration of a proposed project activity; 
(x)  review and finalize the draft project progress report to the RSID project specialist; 
(xi)  review and finalize all other draft reports of the team; 
(xii)  with input from team members, respond to external technical inquiries on the 
CMI; and

(xiii)  perform other CDM-related work under the TA as assigned by the RSID project 
specialist and director. 
  2. CDM Expert (24 person-months) 
3.  The consultant will undertake the following activities: 
(i)  gather and review existing information and data on the CDM in DMCs and ADB 
pipeline projects with potential CDM components, considering the additionality of 
each project; 
(ii)  carry out necessary capacity-building activities as identified by the team leader 
and RSID project specialist; 
(iii)  verify evaluations completed by national consultants on the ADB project pipeline 
to determine the greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions reduction potential;   
(iv)  provide CDM-related technical support to ADB's operations departments, and 
participate  in  missions  as  required  in  consultation  with  national  experts  and 
international technical advisors as necessary, including but not limited to the 
below tasks: 
(a)  prepare CDM assessment reports of projects; 
(b)  prepare PDDs; 
(c)  develop new baseline and monitoring methodologies; 
(d)  assist project entities in gaining approval from host country authorities 
and third-party validators, and register the project with the CDM Executive 
Board; and 
(e)  assist  project  developers  in  implementing  CDM  projects  after  loan 
execution;
(v)  draft progress reports of the projects, and submit them to the team leader; 
(vi)  follow international developments on mitigation of GHG emissions and the CDM, 
and apprise the team leader and the RSID project specialist accordingly; and 
(vii)  perform other CDM-related work under the TA as assigned by the team leader 
and RSID project specialist and director. 
B.  Individual National Consultants 
1. Program Coordinator (24 person-months) 
4.  Reporting to the team leader, this consultant will provide overall assistance during the 
TA’s implementation and support the technical support facility (TSF) team in its operations. This 
consultant will also undertake the following activities: 
(i)  develop a detailed work plan and budget in consultation with the team leader and 
RSID project specialist, and provide assistance in the overall implementation of 
the TA; 
(ii)  assist  the  RSID  project  specialist  in  the  engagement,  management,  and 
evaluation of retainer consultants; 
(iii)  provide  technical  and  logistical  assistance  to  international  and  national 
consultants and various ADB departments in regard to the TA;

Appendix 3  11 
(iv)  organize and participate in regional and DMC-hosted local conferences, and 
provide assistance in report and proceedings preparation; 
(v)  conduct  initial  evaluation  of  consultants’  outputs,  and  make  necessary 
recommendations for action; 
(vi)  prepare monthly and quarterly technical reports on TA operations for submission 
to management and annual program reports for submission to donor agencies 
through the Office of Cofinancing Operations; and 
(vii)  perform other related project tasks as assigned by the team leader and RSID 
project specialist and director. 
  2.  CDM Expert (24 person-months) 
5.  This consultant will support the international consultants and will have expertise in CDM 
and energy projects. This consultant will also undertake the following activities: 
(i)  gather and review existing information and data on the CDM in DMCs and ADB 
pipeline projects with potential CDM components; 
(ii)  compile and analyze evaluations by consultant retainers of ADB pipeline projects, 
and isolate any issues that must be discussed; 
(iii)  assist in drafting the terms of reference for consultant retainers; 
(iv)  assist the international CDM expert and team leader in coordinating with the 
consultant retainers on the development and implementation process of selected 
CDM projects, including the preparation of CDM assessment reports, PDDs, new 
baseline and monitoring methodologies, and host country approval documents; 
(v)  assist the international CDM expert during the implementation phase of selected 
CDM projects, and draft progress reports to be submitted to the team leader and 
RSID project specialist; and  
(vi)  perform other related project tasks as assigned by the team leader and RSID 
project specialist and director.
